semantic_identifier: 4630806 - Kinetic Harbor Renewables - sales_pitch - Discussion with Miguel Dean

hierarchy.meeting_title: 4630806 - Kinetic Harbor Renewables - sales_pitch - Discussion with Miguel Dean

sections.text: Megan Foster: Hi Miguel, Megan Foster here. I know you’ve only got a few minutes—does now still work?
Miguel Dean: Yeah, I’ve got about five minutes. What’s up?

Megan Foster: Perfect. I’m calling because we work with revenue teams that already live in Salesforce or HubSpot but still struggle with two things: forecasting that nobody trusts, and SDRs spending time on the wrong accounts. Our product, Sales_Accelerator, sits on top of your CRM and turns your existing signals—stages, activity, meetings—into an explainable forecast and a “what to do next” list.
Miguel Dean: We already have Salesforce dashboards for forecasting. And our SDRs have sequences. So what’s different?

Megan Foster: Totally fair. The difference is we don’t just summarize pipeline—Sales_Accelerator combines your CRM stage data with real activity signals like last touch, meeting scheduled, stage age, and cycle-time benchmarks to predict commit/best-case/pipeline in a way you can actually defend. Then it shows the drivers behind the number—like “this deal slipped because stage age is 2x benchmark and no next meeting is booked.” It’s meant to cut the end-of-quarter surprises.
Miguel Dean: Okay, but forecasting has never been a software issue for us. It’s more process and people.

Megan Foster: I hear that a lot. The reason I’m calling Kinetic Harbor Renewables specifically is because when teams have process but still see variance, it’s usually because the forecast is being built off stage alone. This adds the behavioral signals automatically, and it gives managers and reps the same set of explainable rules. It’s less “gut feel” and more “here’s what’s missing to make this deal real.”
Miguel Dean: We’re a renewables company. Our cycles are long and weird. Benchmarks aren’t always meaningful.

Megan Foster: That’s exactly why we show the drivers and let you tune the benchmarks by segment—like project type, deal size, source, or territory. It’s not a black box. You can see forecast by segment, rep, and source, and it’ll highlight conversion and slippage patterns unique to your motion.
Miguel Dean: Alright. But you mentioned SDR prioritization too. We don’t have a giant SDR org.

Megan Foster: Understood. Even with a small team, the opportunity cost is huge. One use case we see is: if you’re already doing any kind of fit scoring—like identifying your best target accounts—Sales_Accelerator can pull that in and recommend the next 50 accounts to contact, with tailored openers and proof points by segment so reps aren’t starting from scratch.
Miguel Dean: We don’t have fit scoring. And honestly, we’re not looking to add more tools right now. We’re cutting spend.
Megan Foster: That makes sense. Quick clarification: are you currently on Salesforce or HubSpot?
Miguel Dean: Salesforce. But again—no appetite for new platforms. We’re consolidating.

Megan Foster: Got it. We’re not a replacement CRM—Sales_Accelerator is a layer on top of Salesforce. Typically the pitch is: if you can improve forecast accuracy and reduce slippage, it pays for itself pretty quickly. But if your mandate is “no net-new,” I don’t want to force it.
Miguel Dean: Yeah, our CFO is basically allergic to new subscriptions this quarter.
Megan Foster: Understood. If I asked you one question—where do you feel the most pain: commit accuracy, deals slipping late, or reps not doing the right next step?
Miguel Dean: Honestly, it’s not top three. We’re more focused on delivery and operations right now. Sales is steady.

Megan Foster: That’s helpful. A lot of teams reach out to us when they’re trying to tighten quarter-end execution—scenario planning like “if we add X SQLs in our best segment, what’s the impact?”—but it sounds like you’re not in that mode.
Miguel Dean: Not right now. Maybe later in the year, but I can’t commit to a longer sales call.

Megan Foster: That’s fair. Would it be useful if I sent a one-pager on the forecasting piece—specifically the explainable drivers and slippage diagnostics—so when planning season comes up you have it on hand?
Miguel Dean: You can send it, sure. But I can’t promise I’ll look at it soon.
Megan Foster: Totally okay. What’s the best email for you?
Miguel Dean: miguel.dean@kineticharbor.com
Megan Foster: Great—I'll send something brief. Last thing: is there someone on your side who owns forecasting cadence—sales ops or RevOps—so I’m not bothering you if it’s not your lane?
Miguel Dean: We don’t really have RevOps. Our sales director handles it with finance.
Megan Foster: Got it. If you’re comfortable, could you point me to the sales director’s name, and I’ll keep it light—just share the same overview and see if timing makes sense later?
Miguel Dean: I’d rather not loop anyone in right now. We’re heads-down.
Megan Foster: No problem. I appreciate the candor. I’ll send the one-pager and then I’ll back off—if you want, I can follow up in, say, late Q2 when budgets loosen a bit?
Miguel Dean: Yeah, late Q2 is fine. Just email—don’t call.
Megan Foster: You got it. Thanks for the time, Miguel.
Miguel Dean: Alright. Bye.
